fields.description:
On a single screen, SourceTree's interface is somewhat crowded while viewing the project selections, tiles, branches, source-tree commit history, and diff window with two file lists... you get the picture.

I propose that you allow components of the interface to be un-docked from the main window so that they may be moved to additional screens (preferrably with snap-to at the edges) when available.  My first priority would be unlocking the commit tree as it would allow the diff area to inhabit the entire vertical space, and it would allow a longer view of the commit tree as well.

This same effect can be experienced in GitBash which I found to be much easier to run through diff lists, resulting in more effective / efficient use of my time.  I have to keep the fonts so small in SourceTree to be able to keep larger diff blocks in view that it becomes useless in many cases.
fields.summary: Undockable windows with snap-to on Dual Screen

fields.description: When I open any menu in the menu bar. And, hover over its dropdown, sourcetree crashes. Hovering on right click pop up menu, also crashes the SourceTree.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes when hovering on Menu bar dropdown!

fields.description:
Currently there is no native way to compare the full content of two commits from within SourceTree, you can only compare single files: If you select multiple files and hit the *External Diff* button, SourceTree will open a single instances of your diff tool for every file.

While diffing two full commits is a common feature in git ([difftool --dir-diff|http://git-scm.com/docs/git-difftool.html]) and can easily implemented via a *Custom Action* in SourceTree, it would be cool to have this as a native feature of the UI.
fields.summary: Diff full commits in external tool (dir-diff)

fields.description: When you have a lot of repositories inside a folder, not all repositories are added in alphabetical order. It would be great to have a context-menu item to sort child items inside a tree element in an alphabetical order.
fields.summary: Sort repositories by name inside a folder

fields.description: I have a lot of repositories. I already put them in folders / client, but still there are a lot. It would be great if there would be a quick-filter as TextBox at the top to quickly find (nested) repositories.
fields.summary: Search / filter repositories

fields.description:
When you are going to create a branch you must provide a name. It would be nice if the textfield alongside the Label "New Branch:" could provide some kind of autocompletion regarding namespaces/branch names. 

The workflow could be oriented towards Linux. E.g. I type "fea" -> hit tab key autocompletition to "feature/", than I append "c" -> hit tab, autocompletion to feature/customer and so on. The chooseable possibilities could be  provided via a combobox.
fields.summary: Autocompletion for branch creation dialog regarding namespaces/branchnames

fields.description:
There is a feature that i had have not found in source tree which exit in git extension which is for me very usefull

It is the possibility to view all the file of a project.
This usefully when you want to look for a particular file and look to it's history.

Is there a way to do it, without having to sool for a commit where the file was included first ?

In attachment the gitextension screen

Thanks

Frederic
fields.summary: HAve the possibilities to view all the file of the project

fields.description: If the stashes section in the sidebar is open, clicking the arrow to collapse it causes the program to crash. This has happened twice now.
fields.summary: Collapsing stash section in sidebar causes crash

fields.description: After right clicking to un-shelve changes in Mercurial repo system crashed.
fields.summary: Crashed after unshelving

fields.description:
While trying to apply a Hg patch, source tree crashes.

The path of the patch is currently C:\appcode\fix.patch and was exported from TortoiseHG(mercurial). Switching the patch format in TortoiseHg to git of course fixes this. It would be nice to reject the patch format instead of crashing though.
fields.summary: SourceTree Crashing while trying to apply bad format patch

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# Configure Beyond Compare as merge and diff tool.
# Confirm that the 'external diff' successfully launches Beyond Compare via any Git repository.
# Create a new local Git repository.
# Add several commits.
# Cause a fork, and conflict:
## Developer A deletes a file.
## Developer B edits the file.
# Developer A pushes.
# Developer B pulls (with rebase checkbox selected).
# Rebase is halted due to the conflict.
# Developer B attempts to resolve conflict, by {{Right Click > Launch  External Merge}}

Expected behaviour:
* A message that the remote file was deleted
* Launch of Beyond Compare, with 'remote' being an empty file.

Actual behaviour:
* Beyond Compare never launches and the merge dialogue remains open.
fields.summary: External Merge Fails to Launch When Remote File is Deleted and Local Changed
External Merge Fails to Launch When Remote File Is Deleted, and Local changed - git

fields.description: It would be nice to have a Keyboard shortcut to quickly 'Launch External Merge Tool' especially when you get hit with a large number of merge conflicts!
fields.summary: Keyboard shortcut to quickly Launch External Merge Tool

fields.description:
We hit a lot of whitespace merge conflicts. It would help greatly if we had an option the add the `ignore-space-change` fag when merging. 
And also a preference to make this the default merge behaviour.

git merge -Xignore-space-change feature123
fields.summary: Add checkbox option to allow ignore-space-change when merging

fields.description:
When using interactive rebase and editing the resulting commit message using special characters (mainly skandinavian characters ä and ö in my case) get turned into question marks when the rebase is performed.

For example, "Filtteröintilogiikan muutos" turns into "Filtter?intilogiikan muutos". Same commit message works fine when it used through the regular commit dialog. CLI git also retains the characters.

As a workaround, I can first squash my commits with interactive rebase and then amend the commit to fix the message.
fields.summary: Interactive rebase mangles special characters in commit messages

fields.description:
When starting ST, it always starts in the background/minimzed for me. It doesn't matter if I set the shortcut to ST to maximzed. Even if I do, the program still restores-from-minimized as not maximized.

I just want ST to be maximized no matter what, but its maximized state doesn't seem to be remembered.

When starting a program, one usually wants to start working with it. So starting minimized (what you might call background) makes absolutely no sense to me.

ONLY when starting automatically upon login into windows, it might make sense to start minized, but even then, restoring it from being minimized should still maximize the program, because that's how I left it.
fields.summary: Always starts in the background

fields.description:
Hello,

I want to request a feature that will make tabs to easier to manage. 

Clicking a tab with middle button of mouse should close the tab.

Right clicking the tab should show some options:
- Close the tab
- Close all tabs
- Close all tabs but this
- Close tabs at the right

Thanks
fields.summary: Easly managed tabs

fields.description:
Hello,

That would be great if we can group repository bookmarks. We should be able to collapse the groups.

Right now i have more than 40 repositories in my bookmarks and it's getting harder and harder to find a project in there.
fields.summary: Groupping repository bookmarks
Crash during checkout

fields.description:
I am in the middle of resolving conflicts in a rebase. I hit "ctrl+shift+C" to 'commit' and then select the option to "continue rebase". It then brings up the dialog showing the git command running, and sits there for about 5 full seconds before showing the error as captured in screenshot.

The error is: error: There was a problem with the editor ''C:\Program Files (x86)\Atlassian\SourceTree\stree_gri''.

The file "C:\Program Files (x86)\Atlassian\SourceTree\stree_gri" exists.

There are two files staged and no changes unstaged (see second screenshot).

When I copy/paste the command directly into the command line, I get the same error. If I try selecting "actions > continue rebase" I get the same result.
fields.summary: continuing git rebase failes ("Problem with the editor")

fields.description:
I started an interactive rebase via command line. I was squashing some commits, and HEAD was an ancestor of the 'onto' branch. There was a conflict and I wanted to try resolving it via Sourcetree GUI.

I can right click the file in the "File Status" tab and choose to "resolve using 'theirs'". It tells me that I need to make sure I know which version I'm really saying to use by saying "Please confirm you want to resolve these files using their state as at this commit:", but then fails to actually show the commit hash.

That dialog correctly shows the commit hash their when choosing the resolve via 'mine', and it also works when resolving merge conflicts, and (if I'm remembering correctly) I think it also works correctly when resolving rebase conflicts when 

It's almost like the algorithm for that dialog looks at MERGE_HEAD, but there is no MERGE_HEAD file at that point, but there is the .git/rebase-merge/stopped-sha file instead.
fields.summary: mistake in dialog box during git rebase

fields.description:
When I clone my repo from a Stash server using the "Clone in SourceTree" button, my SourceTree application crashes. The crash occurs when I clone with both the SSH and HTTP protocol.

Here is the stack trace from the log file:

fields.description: See the attached logs.
fields.summary: Source tree crashed on Windows

fields.description: No matter I press "develop" or "origin/develop" in Jump to: drop down menu, the row focus will always go to origin/develop.
fields.summary: UI button "Jump to:" do not jump to right branch flag

fields.description:
It would be very handy for SourceTree to have a full screen mode.
Application title bar, the windows taskbar and the status bar of the application should be hidden in the full screen mode.
fields.summary: Full screen mode

fields.description: I was just collapsing up the remote tree when this crashed.
fields.summary: Crash whilst collapsing remote tree

fields.description:
This is perhaps the biggest quirk about SourceTree that I have found. I make changes to my branch and commit them. I do this a couple of times and then click the push button. By default it selects all of my branches. I may have ten or so branches but only commits on the one I am working on. I click ok and it pushes and then comes back with an error message that says my push failed. I go and pull and try it again. Still failing. Low and behold my push actually succeeded but a push to a branch with no changes failed. First I am not sure why a push of no changes should fail. Secondly why would they need to be checked anyway and why do I get a big red bar and have to click cancel when everything is just fine?

This is even more confusing if you use the check box that says push commits immediately. It will say that your commit succeeded but your push failed. In reality both succeeded and a push to a branch with no changes on it failed. I am used to this by now but i am reminded about it when people new to SourceTree are watching me. 

Them: "Oh your push failed."  
Me: "Actually it worked it just looks like it didnt work"
Them: "Oh, but there was a big red bar and a pop up saying it didnt work"
Me: "Yeah I know"

Yeah, so it is trainable but not very intuitive.
fields.summary: When clicking push, branches with no changes cause the push to fail.
After installation on Windows 8.1 the program pinner to taskbar no long works

fields.description:
When creating a pull request from stash I am redirected to an URL like:

https://<path to repo>/pull-requests?create&sourceBranch=feature%252f<branch name>

which gives me a 404. Changing the URL to

https://<path to repo>/pull-requests?create&sourceBranch=feature/<branch name>

gives e the right page

(i) Didn´t have this error in 1.4
fields.summary: Wrong URL encoding for pull request (%252f instead of /)

fields.description: In the "merge" dialog for git, there is a list of all commits where you need to select which commit to merge. On the upper-right corner of the commit list, there is the usual "Jump to" button. Clicking on it does open the menu as expected, but then no matter if I click on the name of a branch or enter a sha hash, the list does not jump to the requested commit (nothing seems to happen)
fields.summary: "Jump to" in merge dialog does not work

fields.description: We have some systems working and some not, using subtree.  We we attempt to pull or push to the subtree, SourceTree hangs on the progress bar.  If we take the commands and execute them directly in git, they complete.  If there is a merge conflict, git reports it and SourceTree updates correctly.
fields.summary: Subtree hangs

fields.description:
Clone, view commit etc seem to be are working .

when I try to push my username seems to be ignored.

can push with command line git, so the push problem is probably not cause by the server or the repo.
fields.summary: Better help for auth issues / default usernames on hosts

fields.description:
In 
Tools/Options/Diff/Merge Tool 
I selected KDiff3.
KDiff3 is installed in 
C:\Program Files (x86)\KDiff3\kdiff3.exe

I merged a feature branch in master and have a merge conflict.
I rightclick on my file and select 
Resolve Conflicts / Launch external merge tool.
It creates a number of files:
*.BACKUP.*
*.BASE.*
*.LOCAL.*
*.REMOTE*

But it does not launch KDiff3.

Thanks for assistance.
fields.summary: SourceTree does not open KDiff3(1.5.1)

fields.description:
When adding new Tag and Tag name already exists in repository, popup with Move Tag button appears.
But when changes are pushed to remote repository error occurs:

error: failed to push some refs to 'SOME_REPOSITORY_NAME'
hint: Updates were rejected because the tag already exists in the remote.

Old tag from remote must be manually removed via git command:
git push origin :refs/tags/MOVED_TAG_NAME

So this process could be automated.
fields.summary: Move dupliacted tag in remote repository as well

fields.description: In some SVN clients all the commits in the commits view have a mark of the branch they belong to. In SourceTree this feature is missing, so it is quite difficult to work with a complex branch structure.
fields.summary: Add branch name to commit view

fields.description:
Sourcetree hangs immediately after running the following clone command - 
----
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false clone --recursive repo_address.git /cygdrive/c/code/repo_address
warning: templates not found C:\cygwin\share\git-core\templates

Cloning into '/cygdrive/c/code/repo_address'...
---

A folder is created at the correction location, and the .git dir is visible, but only objects, ref, config and HEAD are inside. Nothing progresses past this point. 

I can only imagine this is asking for a password in the background, but not being shown to me? SSH key is set up and working, which is odd. 

Cloning the same repo (and I've tried a few!) via command line Cygwin works as expected. This is the workaround I'm using currently, then adding them in as working copies within sourcetree.
fields.summary: Git clone refuses to clone

fields.description: See attachment. The repository bookmarks on left highlight the list selected one. This doesn't reflect the open repository tab selected. In my example r33 bookmark is highlighted, but the master repository tab is selected.
fields.summary: Repository bookmarks highlighting doesn't reflect selected tab

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
* Commit file that has line endings as CRLF
* Change any line in committed file
* Discard Hunk or selected lines of the change.
* Check for uncommitted changes (ensure ignore whitespace is off)
Expected result: No changes detected in file
Actual result: line endings for entire file have changed to LF only.

This behavior is not exhibited when discarding the entire file.
fields.summary: Discard Hunk/Discard Selected Lines changes CRLF to LF

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# create a new branch called "test,branch"
# switch to a different branch
# attempt to switch back to the newly created branch
#* note that the new branch shows up as "test" in log/history view (truncated at the comma)
#* the following error is displayed: _error: pathspec 'test' did not match any file(s) known to git._

Either branches with commas should not be allowed to be created, or Sourcetree should properly handle special characters in the branch name
fields.summary: Git branches can be created with a comma in the name, but can't be checked out

fields.description:
Added error log below in the comments. 

---------------

It was a problem i posted before about but i have not had the need for a while to use my home laptop. Now i tried it again after the 1.5 update (removing all files / appdata and fully uninstalling it to find tit once again crashing as soon as i opened the application ). The weird thing is also that their are no error logs.

Original post: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/263463/sourcetree-1-4-10-crashes-on-windows-8-1

------------

I am experiencing the following problem even after removing all appdata and reinstalling the program keeps crashing on windows 8.1 making it unusable. The weird thing at work i run it on windows 8.1 to where it works without a problem.

Generally what happens is it starts up okay, but the moment you try to open a window the content of the window is not rendered (buttons that are somewhere on the window do work though dont know why) after a few seconds though the whole application crashes.

Edit: Photo for clarity:
http://s19.postimg.org/hzt4yf8df/sourcetree_crash.png
fields.summary: Sourcetree 1.4.10 and now 1.5 crashes on windows 8.1

fields.description:
This applies to Options -> Diff -> Change Font...

Unlike the Options window, the Choose Fonts window has no margin between the window border and the first button.  (Options has a StackPanel of buttons with Margin=5, but Fonts has a StackPanel with Margin=0,5)  This makes the Cancel button butt up right next to the edge of the window.

It would be if the Margin was 5 for the Choose Fonts window, too.

Thank you for the excellence that is SourceTree!
fields.summary: Move Cancel/OK button in Choose Font window left a little bit.

fields.description: Please support the prepare-commit-msg GIT hook. We are prefilling the message with data from our Issue Tracking system and it would be cool to use SourceTree for Commits.
fields.summary: Support prepare-commit-msg hook

fields.description: It would be nice to be able to close the console output dialog by pressing the escape key.
fields.summary: Support Escape-Key to close Console Output Dialog

fields.description: I opened submodule folder on the SourceTree IDE but the IDE is terminated.
fields.summary: SourceTree terminated by submodule folder

fields.description:
https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/282120/password-not-persisting-after-1-5-1-update

After taking the recent update I'm getting intermittent prompts to enter my password. After authentication I am correctly gaining access to my repo but some seemingly random number of minutes later am getting prompted again.

thx
fields.summary: Password not persisting

fields.description: When pushing a commit in I would like to see some form of progress bar, be it for each file or an overall progress bar.
fields.summary: View upload progress

fields.description:
When creating a branch wich name contains accents (e.g. "ejecución") Source Tree fails silently.
If you create a shelve with a name with accents the shelve name is showed incorrectly in the left side bar.  If you try to unshelve Source Tree says that the shelve doesn't exists.
fields.summary: Accents support

fields.description:

fields.description:
In the current BETA version the bookmarks aren't saved correctly. 

- If I rename a bookmark on next opening it shows the old name again. 
- If I move the folder of a bookmark and adjust it in Source Tree it's not saved and on next opening I have to point the correct (new) folder again
- If I add an existing local Git repository and assign a bookmark it shows up correctly but gets lost on next opening
- I can't even delete a bookmark

Please fix this ASAP!
fields.summary: Bookmarks aren't saved

fields.description:
Hi Adam,
I’d like to open a ticket for an issue we had with SourceTree version 1.4.1.0.  I guess we would call this a feature request.  It doesn’t really qualify as a bug.
SourceTree stores authentication information for remote servers.  If my password on the remote server changes and I fail to update it on SourceTree, operations like pull requests fail with failed authentication as the reason.  That works as expected.
 
What wasn’t clear is that every ten minutes SourceTree contacts the remote server for all repos.  If the password stored in SourceTree is incorrect it never notifies the user that these operations fail.   We use Stash configured for delegated LDAP so the net effect is that SourceTree asks Stash to authenticate a user with a bad password, Stash forwards to our internal LDAP directory.  Authentication fails.  LDAP detects too many failed logins and locks the account across all systems using LDAP (along with sending a nasty note about DDOS).
 
Request:
Alert the user when authentication fails. Stop trying after several failed attempts.
 
Notes:
There is a chance that this should be a behavior change in Stash instead of or as well as in SourceTree.
fields.summary: SourceTree should notify users when authentication fails on remote repos if stored password in SourceTree is incorrect

fields.description:
I'm encountering an issue where new files pulled from a subtree are being placed in the root of the repository, rather than the local relative path as specified in the Add / Link SubTree dialog.

If I move these files to their proper location, and pull changes, the files are updated in the correct location.

\\

This may be related to this discussion on stackoverflow;  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1306595/git-confused-when-merging-an-update-into-my-subtree.

From the accepted answer 

??citation??
Unfortunately this is a bug (or missing feature) in the "git merge -s subtree" code. It actually guesses the subtrees that you want to merge. Usually, this magically turns out to be correct, but if your subtree contains a lot of changes (or was originally empty, or whatever), then it can fail spectacularly.
??citation??

The folder was originally empty, but subsequent pulls that contain new files still drop those new files in the root.

\\

The paths I have been using;

Shared code repo is at

\\DISCOMBOBULATOR\Repository\Visual Studio\Common\TAA Interfaces

Main repo is at

\\DISCOMBOBULATOR\Repository\Visual Studio\biotools

Initial setup for Local Relative path when defining the subtree is

\\DISCOMBOBULATOR\Repository\Visual Studio\biotools\Common\TAA Interfaces

When when viewed after saved is recorded as

Common\TAA Interfaces.


\\

More discussion at https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/282022/subtree-pull-hangs-or-pulls-into-the-wrong-folder
fields.summary: subtree pulls drop files in the root of the parent repository

fields.description:
I have been experiencing an issue where the subtrees I have defined in SourceTree disappear after closing and restarting.

Since I had been having a lot of problems, I had been recreating the subtrees a fairly large number of times.  Not sure if its related.

I eventually managed to fix this by deleting the contents of the subtree-cache in the .git folder.

I've attached the contents of the folder, not sure if its of any use.  Hopefully it is.


More discussion at https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/282022/subtree-pull-hangs-or-pulls-into-the-wrong-folder.
fields.summary: Subtree entries in GUI disappearing after closing and reopening SourceTree

fields.description:
Steps undertaken:

Create a new subtree in SourceTree, and use bitbucket as the source.

* Bring up the Add/Link Subtree dialog, and click the Browse Hosted Projects button.
* Select a hosted repository from the list in the Hosted Repository Dialog.

At this stage, you are returned to the first dialog. My Source path is set to
https://email@idtgroup.com@bitbucket.org/...

This cannot be resolved (two @'s), and the repository type fails to be determined. I'm assuming that this is due to the details I supplied when I set SourceTree up initially.

* Change the Source Path / URL to;
https://username@bitbucket.org/...

* Proceed through the dialog setting local relative path, hit OK.

* Select the new subtree and attempt to pull.  

SourceTree recorded this error in the log, and hung with the pull dialog open, progress bar spinning.

{code}
2014-04-10T10:17:28: Could not determine repository from: 'https://email@idtgroup.com@bitbucket.org/idtgroup-dev/taa-interface-libraries.git', output was:
fatal: unable to access 'https://email@idtgroup.com@bitbucket.org/idtgroup-dev/taa-interface-libraries.git/': Could not resolve host: idtgroup.com@bitbucket.org
{code}


The Source Path / URL was definitely specified in the subtree dialog as

https://username@bitbucket.org/idtgroup-dev/taa-interface-libraries.git

not

https://email@idtgroup.com@bitbucket.org/idtgroup-dev/taa-interface-libraries.git

\\

For further reference, more discussion is at https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/282022/subtree-pull-hangs-or-pulls-into-the-wrong-folder
fields.summary: SourceTree is not honoring subtree Source Path / URL when defining a bitbucket source.

fields.description:
your tabbing system is broken. on windows, ctrl tab will move the 'tab cursor'... so in some instances, ctrl tab does what ctrl1,2,3 does. I was simply trying to not use my mouse; tried to tab out of the focus tabs (ctrl1,2,3), and then it crashed. 

I don't mind the crash. but please fix the tabbing system. perhaps binding different keys may prove to be more useful.
fields.summary: Crash log

fields.description:
From the SourceTree window, view a entry, then on the Log/History tab, pick a file and right click 'Blame Selected'.

We are using Rhapsody, so the files are very large and hard to navigate.  In some cases, I was trying to double click in the right scroll pane, and it was starting the version log instead of scrolling.  This does not always seem to happen though.

Line numbering seems to be broken if you grab he right scroll bar and click/drag it.  For long files, the window starts to show the same line number for multiple lines, especially near the end of the file.  The beginning of the file will be ok, but I tried to browse to a known line number from another editor, and noticed as as drat the scroll down, line numbers start to repeat for many lines in a row.

Secondly, would you be able to add a search to this window?  For a 8000 line file, it is hard to navigate to the section to view.

Thank you,
Kevin
fields.summary: Git Blame window usage issues

fields.description: Source tree lets me know there is a new version but when it tries to download the new install it says wrong file size??? Then stops
fields.summary: Unable to update automatically to new version

fields.description:
When only one file is selected in the staged changes section, pressing the commit button will lead to the commit page where you _have to_ commit *all* of the staged files, as the checkboxes are disabled. Choosing 2 files (pressing CTRL for example) and then pressing the commit button while lead to the commit page with all the checkboxes enabled, having the checkboxes corresponding to the file you selected earlier being already checked.

It would be nice to fix this bug =)
fields.summary: Single File Commit Not Working

fields.description:
The program do not view russian symbols (charset is look like ~cp1251).
Example video http://youtu.be/krzyM1AgoN0
fields.summary: Russian charset

fields.description: Something about the attached code causes SourceTree to butcher the diff and output what I can only assume are Chinese characters. See the screenshot. Let me know if you need anything else to resolve this. Thanks and SourceTree is awesome!
fields.summary: Incorrect diff

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# Open a Git repository.
# Go to {{Repository > Interactive Rebase... }}
# A new "loading" screen pops up. Press "Cancel".
# The rebase action is not cancelled and a new screen is shown. Press "Cancel" once again.
# The previous "loading" screen pops up again. The rebase is canceled but for a few seconds the repository information shows that the repository has been rebased.
fields.summary: Can't Cancel Interactive Rebase

fields.description: Says something about changed ssl key so I accept and it just crashes
fields.summary: Keeps crashing

fields.description:
I have a file with a large number of hunk differences (6451 lines from git-diff with diff output of ~1/2 MB).

SourceTree is showing up to only 63 hunks--much less than there are for the file. The lowest hunk is only partially displayed with an ellipsis. This lowest hunk is not even showing a diff but only the previous context lines.

These first 63 hunks are only one line differences. In any case, it seems that SourceTree shouldn't have such a small limit for displaying diffs.
fields.summary: Only 63 hunks displayed, and lowest hunk is partial with ellipsis

fields.description:
When projects are linked between Jira and Stash, it would be cool to send the 
"optional extended integration" settings to sourcetree and also the commit text links
fields.summary: When branching from jira and cloning in sourcetree, send the config to sourcetree

fields.description: When I pulled my Library project as subtree I named it with spaces it pulled fine but going to push changes it only showed the first word in the name and failed. After deleting the subtree and naming with no spaces it now works.
fields.summary: Can't have spaces in Subtrees

fields.description:
The Custom argument allows it to be configured just fine but you may want to add it in the drop down.  It is a paid for product so you may not have as many people using it but it has features that other diff/merge tools do not have.

Reference:
http://www.semanticmerge.com/documentation/main.shtml#ConfigureAtlassianSourceTree
fields.summary: Configuration option for SemanticMerge as a DiffTool and MergeTool

fields.description:
Imagine I would like to ignore a path.
- I right click a new file - placed in a sub-sub-folder
- Select "Ignore"
- Open the Dropdown near "Ignore everything beneath"
- Select a value
- Click "Ok"

=> It ignores the file "Ignore exact filename(s)" insead of the selected value of "Ignore everything beneath".

Better: 
- Select the "Ignore everything beneath"-option if the corresponding value is changed.

This will save an additional click and brings better handling.
fields.summary: Ignore everything beneath should get selected if value is changed

fields.description:
As the number of commits that need to be interactively rebased grows, the GUI underneath for context/filnames/commit message shrinks.  If enough commits are selected (30+?) only the bottom buttons are displayed. and no scrollbar appears to be able to scroll through commits.  In addition you cannot drag the UI to resize it to bring back the bottom UI elements if you select a large number of commits.  To make everything but the bottom buttons dissappear entirely I had to select ~ 60 commits however this may be resolution dependant.

Steps to reproduce:
*Create a repo with > 60 commits
*Attempt to interactive rebase near the start of the repository.

Expected behaviour would simply allow scrolling inside the top window without the UI for commits expanding at all.
fields.summary: Interactive Rebase: Rebasing a large number of commits causes the GUI to expand too far/Is not scrollable

fields.description:
Whichever commit you right click the first time upon opening SourceTree, that commit number will show up in all future right clicks inside that repository (other tabs will pick their own respective "first right click"'s.)

The resulting gui selects the correct commit anyway so this is minor.  A simple fix would be to just structure it as the rest of the menu ("<Command>...") and label it as "Rebase Interactive..." or similar.
fields.summary: Interactive Rebase: Right click context menu in Log/History View shows wrong commit number.

fields.description:
The "Squash with previous" button in the interactive rebase sheet causes the selected commit to be squashed with the next commit, chronologically speaking.

This is all pretty confusing because of the ambiguity of the word "previous", and also because the list of commits doesn't show a date or otherwise help the user understand what order the commits are being listed in. The command line version of git rebase -i shows commits with the oldest at the top and the newest at the bottom, so "previous" is unambiguous.
fields.summary: Interactive Rebase: "Squash with previous" squashes with next, not previous

fields.description:
Here's what I did (and have been able to reproduce several times without fail):

- Created a new repo in an empty dir
- Added a (default) remote, 'origin'
- Added an empty text file, committed it (sha1: 6173aec)
- Pushed that commit upstream to my remote
- Created a new branch 'test' and checked it out
- Added a line to my text file, committed the change (sha1: c64a049)
- Added another line to my text file: committed that change (sha1: b041546).
- Pushed my 'test' branch upstream to 'origin'
- Checked out my local 'master' branch
- Merged local 'test' branch into local 'master' branch via context menu on Branches in SourceTree (ticked the 'Create a new commit even if fast-forward is possible' option). New commit's sha1: 062cb6b. At this point, my local 'master' branch is 3 commits ahead of 'origin/master'.
- Switched focus to the 'Log / History' tab for this repo in SourceTree.
- Selected 'Interactive Rebase...' from the 'Repository' menu and the dialog appeared.
- I clicked the 'Cancel' button without interacting with any other part of the 'Interactive Rebase' Dialog.

At this point, the rebase proceeded anyway (expanded the 'show details' view on the progress dialog and saw Rebasing (2/2) which seemed odd) and effectively my changes from my 'test' branch were replayed on top of 'master'. After it finished, my merge commit (sha1: 062cb6b) was gone and SourceTree showed that 'origin/test', 'test', and 'master' all pointed to the same commit, b041546.
fields.summary: 'Cancel' Button on Interactive Rebase Dialog Does Not Abort Rebase

fields.description:
The re-orderable tabs introduced in SRCTREEWIN-766 work fine, but the cursor displays a plus (+) icon when dragging the tab. This would indicate that the tab is being copied, not moved.
Use the move cursor, not the copy cursor.
fields.summary: Wrong cursor for re-orderable tabs

fields.description:
With my Wacom Tablet I'm unable to do a right click within Source Tree. All other programs are working fine but within Source Tree I have to switch to my touch pad to be able to right click. Do you have any idea what happens?

I have to stop the "Windows pencil server" which is restarted a few seconds later.
fields.summary: Problem with Wacom tablet

fields.description: I usually want to see all files in "File Status" to be able to search within and do a log or blame. On the other hand I only want to see all pending changes in the "Log / History" tab. But O noticed that each time I switch one select box the other one is switched as well. Please save the state for each select box on its own to be able to define different states!
fields.summary: Decouple state selection from "File Status" and "Log / History"

fields.description: Instead of requiring opening of git repository in view it would be great to be able to fetch and pull without opening repository
fields.summary: Fetch and pull from the left side launcher

fields.description: Can we please have Stashes grouped into folders via their branch prefix, much like branches are?  It would make it much easier to find stashes one is looking for.
fields.summary: Group stashes by folder

fields.description: It would be nice to have the same text editor for a normal commit when editing a message on rebase.
fields.summary: Allow rich text editing when editing commit message on rebase.

fields.description: Allow the initiate git flow prompt to save settings as default. (i.e. default tag prefix is always v)
fields.summary: Allow Git-Flow save settings

fields.description:
I would love this: https://github.com/blog/1816-partial-commits-in-github-for-mac feature.  

Here is the post content:

Sometimes when you’re in the zone, you get a ton of work done before you have a chance to pause and commit. You want to break the commit down to describe the logical changes you’ve made, and it doesn’t always break down cleanly file by file. You want to select some parts of your changes to commit at a time. That’s easy in GitHub for Mac.

Select one or more lines to commit by clicking on the line numbers in the gutter. In the latest release, you can select a block of changes at a time. Hover over the right hand side of the line numbers to get a preview of what will be selected, and click to select.

!https://camo.githubusercontent.com/b0ad0f59960fc3078789585373f5171b8fe4c7d7/68747470733a2f2f6769746875622d696d616765732e73332e616d617a6f6e6177732e636f6d2f626c6f672f323031342f626c6f672f6d61632d73656c6563742d62792d6368616e67652e676966!

You can select multiple lines or blocks of changes by clicking and dragging. The left of the line numbers will select line by line, and the right will select block by block.

Now you can commit your selected changes, leaving the rest for a later commit.
fields.summary: Partial Commits

fields.description:
Currently it isn't possible to reverse/revert a merge commit in SourceTree for Windows (git revert -m ....) in any way that I can find.  It would be a usefull feature. 

(Perhaps a note about the slightly unexpected(?) behavior on future merges of the branches should be added?).
fields.summary: Allow reverse (i.e. revert) of merge.

fields.description: Please use a fixed size font for the pull window. If I pull from origin, git shows me a diffstat, but this diffstat is completely distorted, because of the proportional font
fields.summary: Use fixed size font for pull window

fields.description:
Hello,

I originally posted this question here https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/272323/sourcetree-slowness-on-windows but did not get any answers that solved my problem. I will cross-post here along with suggestions from the thread that I tried and their results.

I am finding that SourceTree on Windows 7 is incredibly slow to refresh after any action, whether that is staging a file, committing/pulling/pushing, refreshing after a tracked file has been updated, or pressing the commit button. As a test I added a line to a file and to stage and commit that file took at least a minute. Some details:

1.  The laptop I'm using is well speced: i7, 8GB RAM, SSD so I don't think it is the problem.

2.  I only have one repo in SourceTree which is 1GB on my local disk but 99% of that is in a folder which is ignored in .gitignore. I downloaded the repo as a zip file from Github, extracted it and it was 74MB. The repo is hosted on Github and but is private so I am unable to link it.

3.  I am running version 1.4.1 but have experienced the same slowness on 1.4.0 and 1.3.3 (I downloaded these to test this problem).

4.  The Xray unit testing framework () is included as a sub-module but the slowness pre-dates the inclusion of this.

5.  I have 'Show pending' selected in the drop down menu.

6.  I tried to run a few simple commands in Git Bash - add, and status - and they were slow but possibly not quite as slow as in SourceTree. Definitely a lot slower than I've seen on colleagues' identically speced computers with the same repo. I am using embedded Git - version 1.8.3. For clarity my colleagues are using Git Bash, not SourceTree.

7.  I ran git count-objects and there were just under 2000 objects totally around 2MB. Foolishly I closed the window before I got the exact numbers but they were in that region. I've run git gc but haven't noticed any improvement.

I would love to get to the bottom of this issue because SourceTree is by far the best Git client I have ever come across. Please let me know if you require any further information.
fields.summary: Slowness on all operations

fields.description:
I have unticked the "Allow Sourcetree to modify your global Git & Mercurial config files". Using CNTLM behind a corporate productivity firewall so the proxy is set to ...
{code}
[http_proxy]
# using CNTLM.
host = localhost:3128
{code}
Every time I open Sourcetree's options and click ok it deletes the proxy information from mercurial.ini. 
Stop it!
cheers
fields.summary: deletes http_proxy settings from mercurial.ini

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# Create a tag in a Git repository. Eg.: Tag1
# Click on a commit that is associated to the tag.
# The summary section of the commit contains an "orphaned comma" before the tag name: "Labels: tag:, Tag1"
fields.summary: Tags Are Displayed Incorrectly Under Labels

fields.description:
Taken from: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/204810/using-stash-in-sourcetree

The Stashes are visible on the "left sidebar," situated between the Bookmarks and the File Status, Log / History, and Search views. There is a context menu for each Stash that will let you Apply or Delete a saved stash.

This really needs improvement.

I had managed to resize my "left sidebar" so that it was completely hidden (well, not obvious that it was there at any rate). The only thing that looked like a "left sidebar" to me was the Bookmarks sidebar. As a result I spent a half hour trying to make sense of the few support answers I could find.

Two things would make this better. 1) Make the resize of the left sidebar more clear. Somehow make it obvious that there is content hidden when the sidebar is collapsed and make it easy to reset it back to appropriate dimensions. 2) Provide a GUI wizard to make unstashing as easy as stashing and put the action alongside the Stash icon in the toolbar. Additionally, provide a command in the Repository menu that is clearly the command partner of Stash.
fields.summary: Stash improvement request

fields.description: Booted up today and Sourcetree crashes as soon as I try to commit or pull. And it times out when I try to check for updates.
fields.summary: Crashing when attempting to pull or commit

fields.description:
I was just rebuilding one of my applications in Visual Studio which takes around 15 minutes to completely rebuild. During that time SourceTree was using 22-25% CPU for the entire operation (i.e. almost an entire CPU core as I have 4 cores). 

It's window was not active, but was visible on another monitor, and I could see it repeatedly refreshing the list of working copy changes and the git staging area looking for changes.

It looks to me as though it is still receiving and processing directory change notifications even when it is not the active window - I thought that it wasn't supposed to do that.
fields.summary: High CPU usage when a build is underway but SourceTree is not the active window

fields.description:
UPDATE: Just realized that there is an option to set a fixed-width font and to mark certain character limits. This issue can be closed.

When writing a commit message, it would be nice to know how many characters the current commit message is so the message doesn't violate the 50/70 rule.
fields.summary: Character Count on Commit Message

fields.description:
When cloning and performing any push or pull function to a server on the Internet there is currently no indication that anything is transferring.  The commits are listed but the file transfer just sits there!

A very simple total KBytes up/downloaded divided by the number of seconds, shown near the scrolling blue bar, would give some confidence that the network connection is at least working.

Many thanks.
fields.summary: Show the download and upload speed

fields.description: Source tree asks for update when current version is already loaded. Noticed the problem in version 1.4 still an issue in 1.5.  It notifies the user on launch that there are updates available but lists versions currently installed. If an update attempt is made it takes you through the repair or modify options and then fails on install.
fields.summary: Source Tree asks to update

fields.description: It would be nice to be able to view a log of all the git/hg commands that SourceTree has executed and their output. Similar to the "show full output" option for the currently executing command but for all commands executed in the current session.
fields.summary: Command log

fields.description:
I routinely push one of my repos to two remotes.  Currently I have to do the push twice, and select the remote each time.  

It'd be nice if the dialog allowed a push to both (or selected) remotes in one go.

~~~
Related, the push icon on the main page helpfully indicates if the local repo has pending commits that need to be pushed, but this is only with respect to the remote most recently pushed to.  It'd be better, I think, if it showed the a number if any of the remotes are behind (perhaps this could be configurable from a revamped push dialog, too).
fields.summary: Improve the push dialog to push to multiple remotes at the same time.

fields.description:
We have a repository which has colons in some of the filenames. These generate an error when checked out on windows. It would be awesome if sourcetree could transparently translate them to something Windows likes and back again when submitting.

Though this may be more of a git problem, perhaps sourcetree could work around it somehow.
fields.summary: Git: files with colons in them cannot be cloned

fields.description:
I am using Source Tree under windows server 2012, the icons of the source tree do not align to to the row. Please see the attachment for more details.
I don't know what other information I need to provide, please email me if you need more information.
fields.summary: Icons in Windows server 2012 do not align to the row

fields.description:
Hi, I have git.user.name and email configured correctly with git and everything looks right in SourceTree but the name does not get populated correctly in the commit window.

UPDATE:
I noticed that if I set the username and email for the repo it would work. Note that I didn't have any entry in the repo .gitconfig before at all. SO it looks like the global is being ignored 

ANOTHER UPDATE:
We have found that if you manually enter the Author for one commit that SourceTree seems to remember it. This is still on a per-repo basis.

Please note that out of a large group of developers (80-90) this is impacting a sizable number of them (maybe 10-20%)

YET ANOTHER UPDATE:
This problem seems to extend to other things than just the name. Developers are reporting the same thing about merge tool configurations. SourceTree was not launching the chosen mergetool, we found that if the developers copied the mergetool configs from the global .gitconfig into the local-repo .gitconfig then everything worked. So it seems SourceTree is ignoring the global.
fields.summary: SourceTree Missing author for commit

fields.description:
First thanks for your great software, i'm a big fan of source tree.

This just a small improvement suggestion.

When you click on the Pull button, by default only the select branch is checked.
When you click on the Push button, by default it select all the local branch.

I really appreciate if the Push can work like the Pull, by default just select the selected branch. Just like when you right click on the branch and do a Push to origin.

Indeed this can maybe just a settings to change the default behaviors.

Thanks for your work

Fred
fields.summary: Allow the "Push" tool bar button to select only the selected branch

fields.description:
If I change my global username value in .gitconfig using any editor (not SourceTree), when I open Sourcetree I see the old values in the Tools->Options menu.

See https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/173818/how-to-reload-global-user-information-in-sourcetree
fields.summary: SourceTree won't reload global user info

fields.description: Whenever sourcetree wants to communicate with bitbucket it keeps popping up the authentication window. Even though I have checked the remember password dialog, it keeps reappearing when I clicked OK
fields.summary: Authentication window keeps popping up

fields.description:
When doing a commit of a large subfolder's files (~1000), the commit action dialog stops, showing the log with the huge command-line of filenames that is many pages long... and it is not obvious that it failed unless you scroll down to the bottom of the many pages and see the "commit failed with errors.... see above".  However, there is no errors that I can find, so I cannot tell you why it failed.
I then performed the commit of the same files usinig TortoiseGit and it worked fine.  
I could go back to a different branch that still contains those files, and retry the commit, if you want me to gather some other info.
fields.summary: Commit is unsuccessful with many (~1000) files

fields.description:
The "are you sure" warnings that Sourcetree emits pretty often are a major annoyance for me.  I frequently find myself wanting to do things like go to a state with a detached head, revert changes without saving, or resolving conflicts one way or another.  All of these produce "are you sure" warnings, and they add up to a noticeable slowdown in my workflow.  I wish I could turn the warnings off.  The best way to do it would be to put a "don't show again" checkbox into each such window.

Also, a bit of philosophy behind this -- one major purpose of version control is that if you screw up, you won't lose too much work.  This is even more true with distributed VC -- even deleting an entire repo on one machine would not cost me too much.  That being the case, I DON'T need to be protected from screwing up.  Because even if I do, it won't cost me much.  The time lost to the protection is greater than the time I would lose to the occasional mistake.

All this applies equally to Mac.
fields.summary: Option to turn off warnings
